original_data.question: A 60-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic complaining of severe vulvar itching that has been gradually worsening for the past year. She mentions that she has tried over-the-counter lubricants, but lubricants do not seem to provide substantial relief. Her medical history is remarkable for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Menopause occurred at 52 years of age. She has been sexually active with her husband until recently and reports severe pain during vaginal intercourse. The physical examination reveals dry, thin, white plaque-like lesions in the vulvar area with atrophy of the labia minora. The clitoris appears retracted. The perianal skin appears pale and wrinkled. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.C: Squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva

model_response:
This patient's presentation is most consistent with lichen sclerosus. Lichen sclerosus is a chronic inflammatory mucocutaneous disease that primarily affects the anogenital region. It is most common in postmenopausal women, although it can occur at any age. The etiology is unknown, but it is thought to be an autoimmune disorder. The patient typically presents with itching and soreness in the vulvar area. On examination, the skin is usually white and crinkled, with marked hypopigmentation and superficial fissuring. The labia minora may be atrophic and the clitoris may be buried in the thinned glans. The patient may also have a diffuse whitish discoloration of the vulvar area. The risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva is increased sixfold in patients with lichen sclerosus. Squamous cell hyperplasia is characterized by thickening of the vulvar epithelium due to an increase in the number of cell layers. The lesions appear as well-demarcated, raised, white or pink areas. The clitoris is not usually involved. Lichen planus is a pruritic inflammatory disorder that can affect the skin and mucous membranes. It is characterized by distinct purple, flat-topped papules with a fine scale. The lesions are usually symmetrically distributed and may be found in the trunk, extremities, and genital area. Squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva is the most common malignancy of the vulva, but it is rare. The lesions may appear as a nodule, ulcer, or mass.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Those facilities which administer health services to individuals who do not require hospitalization or institutionalization.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
The external genitalia of the female. It includes the CLITORIS, the labia, the vestibule, and its glands.
An intense itching sensation that produces the urge to rub or scratch the skin to obtain relief.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Compounds that provide LUBRICATION between surfaces in order to reduce FRICTION.
Compounds that provide LUBRICATION between surfaces in order to reduce FRICTION.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
An indication that a subject with diabetes is able to control symptoms by modifying their diet.

A type of diabetes mellitus that is characterized by insulin resistance or desensitization and increased blood glucose levels. This is a chronic disease that can develop gradually over the life of a patient and can be linked to both environmental factors and heredity.

Persistently high systemic arterial BLOOD PRESSURE. Based on multiple readings (BLOOD PRESSURE DETERMINATION), hypertension is currently defined as when SYSTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently greater than 140 mm Hg or when DIASTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently 90 mm Hg or more.

A thiazide diuretic often considered the prototypical member of this class. It reduces the reabsorption of electrolytes from the renal tubules. This results in increased excretion of water and electrolytes, including sodium, potassium, chloride, and magnesium. It is used in the treatment of several disorders including edema, hypertension, diabetes insipidus, and hypoparathyroidism.

The last menstrual period. Permanent cessation of menses (MENSTRUATION) is usually defined after 6 to 12 months of AMENORRHEA in a woman over 45 years of age. In the United States, menopause generally occurs in women between 48 and 55 years of age.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
A response indicating that an individual is or was sexually active.
A male partner in marriage.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
The sexual union of a male and a female, a term used for human only.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Removal of moisture from a substance (chemical, food, tissue, etc.).
Narrow in width, extent or cross-section.
A flat lesion resembling a plaque.
The external genitalia of the female. It includes the CLITORIS, the labia, the vestibule, and its glands.
Decrease in the size of a cell, tissue, organ, or multiple organs, associated with a variety of pathological conditions such as abnormal cellular changes, ischemia, malnutrition, or hormonal changes.
One of the two longitudinal folds of skin located between the labia majora.
An erectile structure homologous with the penis, situated beneath the anterior labial commissure, partially hidden between the anterior ends of the labia minora.
A clinical manifestation consisting of an unnatural paleness of the skin.
A fold, ridge or crease of the skin.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
